author: travelandtourworld.com
title: Visit the 19th Century Camden Park Historic MansionTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Visit the 19th Century Camden Park Historic Mansion
One of Australia’s most important and intact historic houses will open its doors to the public on Saturday, September 19 and Sunday, September 20, 2015, as visitors step back in time into Camden Park House in the Macarthur region.
Built in 1835 for wool industry pioneers John and Elizabeth Macarthur, after whom the region is named, Camden Park House is unique in that it remains the home of the descendants of the original owners, Edwina and John Macarthur-Stanham.
The Georgian mansion’s 80 rooms and picturesque gardens are opened once a year to more than 2000 visitors and the original furnishings ensure that guests can see a window into 19th century life.
John Macarthur commissioned architect John Verge to design a house suitable for his family – one of the colony’s most prominent and wealthy clans at the time. The grand sandstone house was built by convicts assigned to the Macarthurs while the family lived at the nearby Belgenny Farm. However, Macarthur died before the construction was completed in 1935 and his sons James and William Macarthur instead took up occupancy in the new house.
Verge’s striking Palladian design has stood the test of time, as the house remains today largely as it was built. The surrounding farmland still operates as a working dairy farm, producing two million litres of milk each year, and is one of the last remaining in the area.
The mansion will be open from 12pm – 4pm on Saturday, September 19 and 10am – 4pm on Sunday September 20, 2014. In addition to guided house and garden tours, Devonshire teas, refreshments, plants and gift stores and vintage car displays will be on offer, as well as Macarthur history talks and an Australian Armoured Vehicle Association display.
